comments:
The course is designed to teach students how to think as an economist about legal rules; to evaluate alternative legal rules against standards of economic efficiency and distributive justice; and to understand the nature of the legal process and several specific areas of the law. With the use of alternative texts, both deductive and inductive reasoning will be employed to study the formation and interpretation of legal rules.

Most students enjoyed this “very useful and interesting” course with material that is “highly relevant to life in the real world.” However, a few comment that “the class never gained [their] full interest.”

Professor Asher “captured the students’ attention from the first five minutes of lecture.” Students praise his “passion,” his “ability to engage the class in healthy debate,” and the way he “inspires and motivates” the class. Students also appreciate that Professor Asher “went out of his way to make the course relevant by inviting guest speakers and discussing current events.”

This course requires “a lot of reading,” some of which “isn’t relevant to the topics discussed in class.” Although some of the concepts are “difficult,” this course is great for students who wish to “think about social issues with an economic approach.”
